sources.title: Tarzan and the Green Goddess
sources.description: You can find more information regarding this film on its IMDb page .

sources.title: Tarzan and the Green Goddess (1937)
sources.description: Tarzan retells the story of a trip to Guatemala in which the ape-man had gone to aid a friend in searching for a very valuable totem pole called the Green Goddess. Second of two feature versions of the 1935 serial film "The New Adventures Of Tarzan", culled from the serial's last 10 episodes. Watch on RetroFlix:  https://retroflix.org/tarzan-and-the-green-goddess-1937/

sources.title: Tarzan and the Green Goddess (1938) BRUCE BENNETT
sources.description:
Movie Class by PizzaFLIX: Unsatisfied with MGM’s first two Tarzan films, novelist Edgar Rice Burroughs decided not to renew his contract. Instead, he co-founded Burroughs-Tarzan Enterprises with Ashton Dearholt for the filming of THE NEW ADVENTURES OF TARZAN. He aimed to stay true to his novel’s portrayal of Tarzan as a cultured and well educated gentleman, which he succeeded. He also sought greater financial returns, which he did not, and Burroughs was soon back with MGM.  

Stars: Bruce Bennett, Ula Holt, Frank Baker
Director: Edward A. Kull

A sequel of sorts  to the 1935 "New Adventures of Tarzan,"  made from the last ten chapters of the serial plus some previously unused footage.

sources.title: 1943 - Green Goddess - American adventure film directed by D. Ross Lederman
sources.description:
Three Americans (George, Tess, and Doug) en route to Cairo, Egypt, are forced by engine failure to land in Iraq and are taken prisoner by an Arab chieftain.

Directed by William Nigh

Main Cast:
John Loder - George Torrence
Ruth Ford - Tess Torrence
Warren Douglas - Doug Everett
Paul Cavanagh - Sheik Ahmid Bel Nor
Barry Bernard - Devins
Peggy Carson - Timah Devins
Martin Garralaga - High Priest
Bill Crago - Air Force Capt. Carson
John George - Small Iraqi in Courtyard
Manuel López - Tall Priest in Courtyard
Bill Edwards - Air Force Sergeant


B&W version https://youtu.be/KIxVpsFzaDs


https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=UUMOycDFnpMeWzaITQSD1dWsOA

@CultCinemaClassics

sources.title: Tarzan and the Green Goddess (1938) Action, Adventure Full Length Movie
sources.description:
This is an edited version of the 1935 serial "The New Adventures of Tarzan."

At his English manor, Lord Greystoke - aka Tarzan - recounts his recent adventures in Guatemala. He had been there assisting Major Martling and Ula Vale in their quest for the Green Goddess, a totem worshipped by a jungle tribe inside of which was hidden a formula for a super-explosive.

Directors: Edward A. Kull, Wilbur McGaugh
Writer: Charles F. Royal 
Stars: Bruce Bennett, Ula Holt, Frank Baker 
Genres: Action | Adventure

@CultCinemaClassics 
https://www.facebook.com/CultCinemaClassics

https://www.twitch.tv/cultcinemaclassics

metadata.Plot: At his English manor, Lord Greystoke - aka Tarzan - recounts his recent adventures in Guatemala. He had been there assisting Major Martling and Ula Vale in their quest for the Green Goddess, a totem worshipped by a primitive jungle tribe inside of which was hidden a formula for a super-explosive. They had successfully wrestled this totem from the natives and were heading back to Livingston when they were attacked by Raglan, a thug sent to steal the Green Goddess and its formula for Hiram Powers' personal use, and the Goddess is seized from them. On the trail of Raglan, they had to deal with his henchmen and also a party of the primitives, sent by the High Priest to retrieve the Goddess. With the Goddess still in Raglan's hands, they were seized by the natives and Tarzan locked in a small cell with a loosely-tethered lion, Ula in an adjacent cell under guard from a hideous jungle hag, and Martling being forced to watch his bumbling valet, George, being tortured by the natives with the assistance of a nameless expatriate white scientist who had joined forces with the primitives...
metadata.Writer: Charles F. Royal, Edwin Blum, Edgar Rice Burroughs
metadata.Actors: Bruce Bennett, Ula Holt, Frank Baker
